case_name: Union of India, State of Vindhya Pradesh and Collector of Satna v. Legal Representatives of Shri Lal Saheb Bhargavendra Singh

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 738 of 1963.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 738 of 1963.

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and decree dated December 16, 1960 of the Madhya Pradesh High Court in First Appeal No. 105 of 1957.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and decree, dated December 16, 1960 of the Madhya Pradesh High Court in First Appeal No. 105 of 1957.

facts.text: Suit filed on August 10, 1956 by Shri Lal Saheb Bhargavendra Singh (deceased, represented by legal representatives) against Union of India, State of Vindhya Pradesh (merged in Madhya Pradesh), and Collector of Satna.

anchor.surface_text: This appeal arises out of a suit filed on August 10, 1956 by Shri Lal Saheb Bhargavendra Singh, number deceased and represented by his legal representatives, against the Union of India, the State of Vindhya Pradesh, number merged in the State of Madhya Pradesh, and the Collector of Satna,

facts.text: Plaintiff claimed declaration of entitlement to receive Rs. 650 per month allowance from Union of India.

anchor.surface_text: for a declaration that he was entitled to receive an allowance of Rs. 650 per month from the Union of India.

facts.text: Shri Lal Saheb was the brother of the Ruler of the former Indian State of Nagod.

anchor.surface_text: Shri Lal Saheb was the brother of the Ruler of the former Indian State of Nagod and he companytended that the Ruler had by a law passed on March 7, 1948

facts.text: Ruler of Nagod passed order on March 7, 1948 providing allowance of Rs. 650 per month to Shri Lal Saheb.

anchor.surface_text: provided for an allowance for him at the rate of Rs. 650 per month and that law was binding on the defendants who had by an executive order illegally altered the amount of the maintenance.

facts.text: Suit dismissed by trial Court.

anchor.surface_text: The suit was dismissed by the trial Court but was decreed by the High Court of Madhya Pradesh on appeal by the plaintiff.

facts.text: High Court of Madhya Pradesh decreed the suit on appeal.

anchor.surface_text: The suit was dismissed by the trial Court but was decreed by the High Court of Madhya Pradesh on appeal by the plaintiff. Hence this appeal.

facts.text: On March 18, 1948, Ruler of Nagod along with Rulers of neighbouring states formed United State of Vindhya Pradesh, component states merged, lost sovereign status.

anchor.surface_text: Certain events that took place after March 7, 1948 when the allowance was fixed have number to be stated. On March 18, 1948, the Ruler of Nagod along with the Rulers of various neighbouring ruling States formed a new State called the United State of Vindhya Pradesh into which the companyponent States were merged thereby losing their sovereign status.

facts.text: United State of Vindhya Pradesh merged in India by agreement, Government of India took over administration on January 1, 1950.

anchor.surface_text: Thereafter the United State merged in India by an agreement and pursuant thereto the Government of India took over its administration on January 1, 1950.

facts.text: Territories became Indian province of Vindhya Pradesh, United State ceased to exist.

anchor.surface_text: Its territories then became the Indian province of Vindhya Pradesh The United State ceased to exist.

facts.text: On promulgation of Constitution on January 26, 1950, Province of Vindhya Pradesh became Part C State.

anchor.surface_text: On the promulgation of the Constitution on January 26, 1950 the Province of Vindhya Pradesh became a Part C State of Independent India

facts.text: From November 1, 1956, merged with State of Madhya Pradesh.

anchor.surface_text: and later from November 1, 1956 it was merged with the State of Madhya Pradesh.

facts.text: By agreement constituting United State, all laws in force in constituent States continued in force.

anchor.surface_text: By the agreement companystituting the United State all laws in force in the companystituent States were companytinued in force

facts.text: Laws of United State continued in force by statutory order when merged in India.

anchor.surface_text: and likewise, the laws of the United State were by a statutory order companytinued in force when it merged in India.

facts.text: Article 372 of Constitution continued in force all laws in force before commencement.

anchor.surface_text: Article 372 of the Constitution companytinued in force all laws which were in force in the territories of India immediately before the companymencement of the Constitution.

facts.text: Neither United State nor succeeding Indian Province or States made any law concerning allowance to Shri Lal Saheb.

anchor.surface_text: Neither the United State number the Indian Province or States which successively administered the territories of the State of Nagod had made any law companycerning any allowance to be paid to Shri Lal Saheb.

facts.text: Rajpramukh of United State and President of India passed orders fixing allowance at amounts lower than Rs. 650.

anchor.surface_text: The Rajpramukh  the head  of the United State and the President of India had passed orders from time to time fixing his allowance at amounts lower than that at which it had been fixed by the Ruler of Nagod on March 7, 1948.

facts.text: These orders were executive orders, not laws.

anchor.surface_text: These were, however, executive orders and number laws.

facts.text: All this is not in controversy; only question is whether Ruler's order of March 7, 1948 was a law.

anchor.surface_text: All this is number in companytroversy. The only question in this appeal is whether the order of the --Ruler of Nagod of March 7, 1948 was a law.

facts.text: President reduced allowance to Rs. 530 per month by order of September 24, 1951.

anchor.surface_text: It was, therefore, companypetent to the President  1   1962 Supp. 1 S. C. R. 405 acting in his executive capacity to reduce it to a sum of Rs. 530 per month as he did by his order of September 24, 1951 which was challenged in the, suit.

facts.text: Order of Ruler addressed to Chief Minister, directing him to provide kothi, Rs650/month, tonga, horse, Rs5000.

anchor.surface_text: The order of the Ruler of Nagod which is said to be a law, is addressed to the Chief Minister of the State and directs him to do certain things. It starts by reciting that Shri Lal Sahebs financial position was deplorable ... Hence, I order that  the Kothi   in which he is at present residing  be given to Shri Lal Saheb for generation to generation and an allowance of Rs 650  Rupees six hundred and fifty , per month be granted, in addition to the same a tonga and a horse be given, the expenses for which shall be borne by himself and Rs. 5,000  Rupees five thousand , be granted to him so that he may be able to make improvements in agriculture and satisfy his debts  partly .

facts.text: Copy of order sent to Shri Lal Saheb and different departments.

anchor.surface_text: Then we find that a companyy of the order was sent under the, direction of the Revenue Minister to Shri Lal Saheb and various parts of it, to the different departments of the Nagod Administration respectively companycerned with them, obviously with the object that they might be carried out.

facts.text: Revenue Minister directed Accounts Officer to report on provision for Rs. 5,000.

anchor.surface_text: Further, it appears that the Revenue Minister directed the Accounts Officer to make a report regarding the provision to be made for the sum of Rs. 5,000 mentioned in the order.

facts.text: Ruler of Nagod gave evidence that he passed the order under his legislative powers.

anchor.surface_text: We should fore companycluding state that the Ruler of Nagod who made the order of March 7, 1948 himself gave evidence stating that lie had passed the order under his legislative powers.

facts.text: Court held order was not a law, but executive act providing allowance.

anchor.surface_text: For all these reasons we have companye to the companyclusion that the order of the Ruler of Nagod of March 7, 1948 was number a law.

facts.text: Appeal allowed.

anchor.surface_text: In the result, we hold that the appeal must be allowed and we direct accordingly.

holdings.text: The order of the Ruler of Nagod of March 7, 1948 was not a law

anchor.surface_text: For all these reasons we have come to the conclusion that the order of the Ruler of Nagod of March 7, 1948 was not a law.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Applied multi-factor test from Narsing Pratap: order addressed to Chief Minister as direction, circulated departmentally, constituted grant of house/tonga/lump sum/allowance out of moral duty/bounty, not legislative promulgation; distinguished Promod Chandra (no pre-existing rules here)

holdings.text: The order was an executive act of the Ruler providing for certain allowance to Shri Lal Saheb

anchor.surface_text: It was not continued in force after the State of Nagod lost its sovereignty in the circumstances earlier mentioned. The order was an executive act of the Ruler providing for certain allowance to Shri Lal Saheb.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Followed from determination not law under modern jurisprudence and continuation provisions (merger agreements, Art. 372); executive acts alterable by executive

holdings.text: It was competent to the President acting in his executive capacity to reduce it to a sum of Rs. 530 per month as he did by his order of September 24, 1951

anchor.surface_text: It was, therefore, competent to the President acting in his executive capacity to reduce it to a sum of Rs. 530 per month as he did by his order of September 24, 1951 which was challenged in the suit.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Since original order executive not law, not protected by Art. 372 or prior continuations; symmetric executive power allows alteration

holdings.text: The true legal position is that whenever a dispute arises as to whether an order passed by an absolute monarch represents a legislative act all relevant factors must be considered: nature of order, scope/effect of provisions, general setting/context, method of promulgation distinguishing legislative from executive

holdings.text: It is not correct to say that this Court has held that every order of the Ruler is a law made by him; the question has to be determined in each case independently

holdings.reasoning_summary: High Court misconstrued prior decisions (e.g. Madhaorao Phalka); line between functions not clear-cut requires case-by-case via factors

holdings.text: The word 'law' in merger covenant, statutory orders, Art. 372 used in sense acceptable to modern jurisprudence

holdings.reasoning_summary: Instruments involve sovereign rights/transfers; 'law' symmetric to successor states' laws (e.g. Union of India); petitioner's contention implies same quality

anchor.surface_text: The true legal position is that whenever a dispute arises as to whether an Orders passed by an absolute monarch represents a legislative act all relevant factors must be considered before the question is answered the nature of the order, the scope and effect of its provisions,
In the result, we hold that the appeal must be allowed and we direct accordingly.

It is, therefore, not correct to say as the High Court did, that this Court has held that every order of the Ruler is a law made by him. The question whether it is so or not, has to be determined in each case independently.
In the result, we hold that the appeal must be allowed and we direct accordingly.
